entry.title: Dangerous Goods Packing Instructions in Product Compliance
entry.content:
Every year more than 1.25 million dangerous goods shipments are transported by air. With air cargo growth predicted at 4.9% every year over the next 5 years the number of dangerous goods shipments will rise significantly. With so many dangerous goods being shipped by air, safety regulations must be followed precisely. IATA helps identify the risks and works with ICAO (International Civil Aviation Organization) to amend the regulations providing stakeholders with the most current guidelines on how to handle and ship dangerous goods safely. 

One of the data points we have been working on improving and expanding are the Packing Instructions for dangerous goods. We start out on the launchpad and go to the Manage Compliance Requirements Dangerous Goods.  

 From here we can see all the newly updated compliance requirement versions and we are going to choose IATA. IATA’s Dangerous Goods Regulation Manual (DGR) contains a list of approximately 3,000 articles and substances that are commonly shipped by air. We can see the new Packing Instructions and that we have over 2,300 already as part of the system for you to use.

But that is just an overview, in the View Regulatory Data app we can search for a specific UN number, in this case 1090 and see the applicable IATA enclosure-specific data sets along with the hazard label. In this app, you have packing instruction information for both single and combination packaging.

Now we can check the specific code and see the combination packaging info along with any additional requirements. For hazmat to be shipped by air, there are specific procedures to be met. First, the shipper must meet their criteria, such as declaring the shipment as dangerous goods, properly completing the Dangerous Goods Declaration, and adequately preparing the shipment for transport.

 

From an IATA publication we can see that packaging requirements of all types are a top priority when transporting dangerous goods. Safety is job number one when transporting dangerous goods, with SAP S/4HANA for product compliance we aim to make it easier and faster for you to get your products where they need to be.

entry.title: SAP EHS Environment Management - environmental responsibility and regulatory compliance
entry.content:
To assure environmental responsibility, regulatory compliance, and sustainable operations, SAP offers a comprehensive suite of solutions within SAP Environment, Health, and Safety – Environment Management, tailored to the needs of environmental managers, compliance specialists, and sustainability leaders.

At the heart of these solutions is the ability to centrally manage, monitor, and report on environmental aspects across the enterprise – from air emissions to regulatory obligations and waste streams – ensuring alignment with both legal requirements and corporate sustainability strategies.

Emission Management enables organizations to track, calculate, and report air pollutant and greenhouse gas emissions in line with local and international standards. By integrating operational data, it facilitates accurate emissions inventories, regulatory submissions, and transparent reporting, supporting both environmental impact reduction and corporate climate objectives.

Compliance Management provides a structured approach to managing all environmental obligations – whether arising from legislation, permits, or internal policies. Through a central repository for requirements and integrated task tracking, the solution reduces compliance risks, ensures timely execution, and enables clear documentation to demonstrate regulatory adherence.

Waste Management covers the complete lifecycle of waste handling – from identification and classification to transport, treatment, and final disposal – ensuring compliance with environmental regulations and corporate sustainability commitments. It streamlines waste tracking, documentation for hazardous and non-hazardous materials, and reporting for regulatory or internal purposes.

Below, you will find an introductory video for each of these topics, offering a concise overview of the solution scope and a glimpse into the user experience through mini demos. As I look back on my final week in Jaipur, it feels like the culmination of not just a project, but of a journey of growth, collaboration, and shared purpose. What began four weeks ago with introductions, first impressions, and a steep learning curve has now come full circle with a clear strategy, a strong partnership, and lasting memories.

The SAP Social Sabbatical program brings together SAP employees from around the world to support innovative non-profits and social enterprises, helping them tackle real business challenges. Every organisation we’re working with are aligned with the UN Sustainable Development Goals, which makes this experience extremely meaningful, as it is fully aligned with some of my most treasured core values. This opportunity hits close to home — using the skills I’ve built over the years to support communities and businesses doing good in the world has always been a personal pursuit.

This last week marked an important milestone in our work with Bhayli — a women-led initiative that empowers artisans and supports the circular economy by transforming waste into beautiful, meaningful products. Bhayli empowers rural women in Rajasthan by training them to transform waste materials — like plastic bottles and beverage cans — into beautifully handwoven and handcrafted products. You can find more about Bhayli’s mission and vision in their website here and Instagram account here. It was a powerful experience that not only generated practical insights for Bhayli’s growth but also built a deeper sense of connection and shared purpose among everyone involved.

There were moments of debate, brainstorming, and back-and-forth alignment — but that’s exactly what made the process so powerful. Each one of us brought different perspectives, shaped by our backgrounds and experiences, and those perspectives enriched the final outcome. It wasn’t just a project handed over — it was a true collaboration, built on trust and respect.

Our program concluded with the final presentation, where we officially handed over the project deliverables. Standing together as a team, sharing our recommendations, and watching the Bhayli leadership nod with excitement and recognition was a moment of pride. It reminded me why programs like the SAP Social Sabbatical exist: to connect corporate skills with social impact, and to create bridges between business frameworks and grassroots innovation.

The presentation was more than a transfer of work — it was a celebration of the journey we had shared with Bhayli’s team, from long discussions over chai, to creative workshops shaping recycled materials, to aligning on business strategy that will help them grow their mission.

As I reflect on these four weeks, what stands out most are not just the deliverables, but the people and experiences behind them. I think of the chaotic but vibrant streets of Jaipur — the honking symphony of traffic, the monsoon rains, the shared laughter over spicy meals. A big thanks to my extended SAP Team who shared this Journey with me: Evelyn Fromm, Oscar Fonque, Gisela Picaro, Daniel Fritsch, May Seet, Vera Volgina, Sebastian Lutz, Jackson Rogers, Carrie Barth and Vani Barg. Lastly I want to thank my manager Sam Forel for supporting me in this endeavor.

entry.title: Introducing Reporting Scope and Data Collection in SAP Sustainability Control Tower
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of the SAP Sustainability Control Tower as of September 1st, 2025.

Why SAP Developed Reporting Scope and Data Collection

SAP introduced the Reporting Scope and Data Collection feature in Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) to address the challenges organizations face when manually collecting sustainability data. Many customers struggled with decentralized, manual processes – often relying on emails and spreadsheets – which made it difficult to ensure data quality, traceability, and compliance with regulatory requirements. The new feature provides an integrated, workflow-based solution that guides users through the process, ensures relevant KPIs are collected, and supports collaboration between central and local teams. 

What Does the Feature Do?

The Reporting Scope and Data Collection feature enables organizations to:

  • Define which sustainability metrics are relevant for reporting.
  • Configure how data should be collected and who is responsible.
  • Guide users through a structured, form-based workflow for data entry, review, and approval.
  • Track and manage data collection runs for different reporting periods.
  • Ensure data is captured, approved, and stored in a traceable manner. 

Step-by-Step Guide: SAP SCT Applications

1. Manage Reporting Scope

  • Define the scope of sustainability reporting by selecting relevant metrics and organizational boundaries.
  • Set validity dates and add comments for each metric (e.g., materiality, monitoring purposes).
  • Capture the results of double materiality assessments and specify which KPIs require data collection.
  • In this simplified example the organizational boundary is set to Business Region EMEA and the Scope Items are the ESRS items Total energy consumption related to own operations - E1-5 - (37)(AR 35) and Total water consumption - E3-4 - (28a).

2. Configure Data Collection

  • Assign data processors and approvers for each scoped metric and organizational entity.
  • Choose the data collection method (e.g., workflow-based).
  • Ensure responsibilities are clear for each data point to streamline collaboration

3. Configure Data Entry

  • Customize the data entry form for each metric, including the data collection cycle (e.g., monthly, quarterly or yearly) and required breakdowns by a master data dimension.
  • Add instructions and enable relevant dimensions to guide processors during data entry

4. Manage Data Collection Instances

  • Set up data collection runs for specific reporting years and periods.
  • Define start, submission, and approval dates to control the workflow timeline.
  • Generate forms for each reporting period and metric, ensuring timely data collection. 

5. Manage Data Collection Forms

  • Preview and send out data collection forms to assigned processors.
  • Processors enter data and submit for approval; approvers review, approve, or reject submissions.
  • Approved data is published and stored, with full traceability in SCT. 

 

This new workflow-based approach in SAP SCT streamlines sustainability data collection, improves data quality, and supports compliance with evolving regulatory standards.

Feature status and outlook: Currently, the feature supports quantitative metrics and measures for sustainability reporting. In future iterations, SAP plans to include qualitative metrics and basic custom metrics, as well as additional data entry methods, plausibility checks, multi-step approvals and email notifications based on customer feedback.

For further support, please also visit Data Collection Workflow for Quantitative Metrics | SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: SAP Green Token for EUDR: Simplifying Compliance at Scale
entry.content:
The EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) is reshaping how companies source and trade key commodities in the EU. From December 2025, large companies trading commodities such as cocoa, palm oil, soy, rubber, cattle, coffee, and timber must prove their products are deforestation-free. SMEs will follow by June 2026.

The stakes are high. Non-compliance can mean fines of up to 4% of annual EU turnover, blocked shipments, exclusion from public tenders, and long-term reputational damage. Yet most companies are not ready for the deep traceability that EUDR requires, right down to the plot of land where commodities originate.

This is where SAP Green Tokencomes in.

Who is affected by EUDR?

The regulation applies broadly across the supply chain:

  • First-time Operators: Companies that first place commodities on the EU market or export them from the EU. First-time operators must perform full due diligence: collecting data (Article 9), conducting risk assessments (Article 10), mitigating risks (Article 11), and DDS creation & management (Article 4).
  • Downstream Operators & Traders: Companies that make relevant products available in the EU market after they have been placed there. Their obligations focus on record-keeping and referencing upstream due diligence statements (DDS) (Article 4 + 5).
  • Non-EU Suppliers: Not directly liable under EUDR, but they must provide EU customers with verified sustainability data according to Article 9 (geolocation, deforestation-free declarations) or risk losing access to EU supply chains.

This wide scope means global coordination across suppliers, producers, importers, and traders is essential.

 Figure 1. Why EUDR matters

 

Why DDS Management is the Cornerstone

At the heart of EUDR compliance lies Due Diligence Statement (DDS) management. Every operator and trader, regardless of role, must handle DDS in some form:

  • Article 4 (Operators): Operators must create and submit DDS in TRACES, ensuring products are deforestation-free and legally produced.
  • Article 5 (Traders): Traders must manage and reference upstream DDS, keeping records to prove that due diligence was exercised earlier in the chain.
  • Article 9 (Information Requirements): Defines the detailed data each DDS must contain: from geolocation of plots of land to production details, supplier information, and legality declarations.

DDS must be submitted in the EU’s TRACES system and retained for at least five years. Without robust DDS management, companies cannot prove compliance, making it the true cornerstone of any EUDR strategy.
 

Why annual reporting is too risky

Some companies consider preparing one DDS per year to cover all volumes. On paper, this looks simpler. In reality, it creates risk:

  • One bad shipment could invalidate the entire batch.
  • Annual aggregation makes it harder to trace products back to individual plots of land.
  • Errors may only surface months later, when it’s too late to correct them without penalties.
  • Fixed annual DDS volumes may be “used up” too early, forcing resubmissions mid-year.
  • And critically: geolocation data must be collected for each batch regardless. Even if reported annually, the effort is the same — while exposing companies to much higher compliance risk.

In contrast, transactional reporting is safer and more agile:

  • Each shipment is tracked individually, limiting exposure if an issue arises.
  • Errors are detected early, reducing compliance risk and correction costs.
  • Companies maintain continuous oversight instead of year-end surprises.

This is why SAP Green Token is purpose-built for transaction-level traceability and not annual summaries.

 Figure 2. Green Token - Inbounds overview for EUDR

 

How SAP Green Token simplifies EUDR compliance

Green Token was designed to help companies comply with material accounting standards, such as EUDR, at scale. Here’s how:

  • Transactional-level reporting
    Captures data at the delivery level, linking each shipment to origin, sustainability data, and geolocation.
  • Built-in TRACES integration
    Automatically generates DDS, submits them into TRACES, and retrieves reference numbers back into Green Token.
  • Chain-of-custody management
    Maintains segregated accounting for multi-tier, multi-site supply chains, ensuring full auditability.  Because EUDR requires strict segregation of compliant and non-compliant flows, Green Token makes this process automated and auditable.
  • Open API for geo-spatial- and risk tools
    Connects with external geospatial and risk assessment platforms via GeoJSON, enabling Article 10 risk analysis.
  • Audit-ready by design
    Stores DDS and supporting data for 5+ years, with transparent reporting and real-time visibility for inspections.
  • Support for EU and non-EU companies
    Green Token supports operators, traders, authorized representatives, and even non-EU suppliers, enabling them to provide the data EU customers need.

The result: compliance becomes a continuous, automated process, not a manual, reactive scramble.

How it works in practice

Implementing Green Token for EUDR follows five simple steps:

  1. Capture delivery data from ERP or CSV sources.
  2. Map EUDR attributes (geolocation, supplier IDs, DDS reference numbers).
  3. Generate DDS automatically in the correct TRACES format.
  4. Integrate with TRACES to submit DDS and pull official DDS reference numbers back into Green Token.
  5. Store and report data for auditing, with full transaction-level granularity.

This streamlined approach makes it possible for even complex, global supply chains to stay compliant without creating parallel systems or manual overhead.

 Figure 3. Green Token - Set Up Overview

 

Why SAP Green Token is different 

While other solutions focus narrowly on risk assessment or certificates, SAP Green Token delivers enterprise-scale compliance:

  • Transactional-level EUDR attributes & reporting: One of the few solutions that captures DDS data (geolocation, supplier IDs, DDS references) at the shipment/delivery level, instead of relying on aggregated annual reports.
  • ERP-native integration: Reuse supplier, material, and delivery data directly from SAP ERP, no duplicate entries.
  • Scalable for complexity: Handle multi-site, multi-commodity flows and adapt to evolving regulations like EUDR and CBAM.
  • Future-proof: Already supporting Authorized Representatives (Article 6) and ready to adapt to Omnibus updates.
  • Trusted partner ecosystem: Connect with external geospatial and audit partners through open APIs.

Only SAP Green Token combines transactional granularity, DDS Management, TRACES integration, and ERP-native scalability in one platform.

EUDR is not just another compliance exercise. It’s a structural shift in how companies prove sustainability across global supply chains. For operators, traders, and suppliers alike, the key to compliance lies in accurate, auditable, and automated DDS management.

That’s why SAP Green Token is the starting point to make it happen.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) - Climate Action : Corporate Carbon Footprint Calculation(CCF)
entry.content:
This blog outlines the steps involved in tracking and managing emissions from various business activities within different locations to get insights on environmental analysis using "Climate Action" application in SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT).

🌏The earth speaks in colors, whispers in winds, and sings through rivers — if only we choose to listen…🌱

What is Climate Action?

It is the heartbeat of Goal 13 in the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and one of the three main pillars of UNEP (United Nations Environment Programme). Climate Action is taking efforts to tackle climate change and reduce its impacts and adapt to the changes it causes.

SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) - Climate Action functionality  supports organizations to set up Corporate Carbon Footprint (CCF) feature to calculate their sustainability footprint. This feature facilitates the organizations to setup the data  for business activities (for example, Business Travel, Employee Commute) for each respective "Business Location" and calculate the carbon footprint using emission factors in the SAP SCT system.

Mini Note: This feature is distinct from "Data Collection Workflow for Quantitative Metrics". Both the functionalities are meant for collection of data via forms, but the apps, user roles and workflow are different from each other. To be able to use Climate Action - Corporate Carbon Footprint (CCF) calculations directly in SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT), we must run the "Booster" scenario from the SAP BTP cockpit.

Process Overview:

Overall Process Flow

Before we dive into the SAP Sustainability Control Tower-Climate Action process steps, and as part of the Climate Action awareness program, I would like to highlight a few key aspects of the Climate Action...

Did you know that tiny Sand Bubbler Crabs teach us about Climate Adaptation through their behavior?...

Very recently I had a chance to visit one of the coastal places surrounded by the Arabian Sea.  When I was strolling on the beach, a sand bubbler crab behavior caught my attention. I wondered why on earth such a tiny species would make a sand balls, then immediately I took my phone and sat down near its hole and started recording it...as soon as it noticed me, immediately it went into its hole and did not come back for a while...but I was waiting patiently without a movement...finally I captured the sand bubbler behavior. I was wondering why would it do so, and It taught me a big lesson...

Sand Bubbler Crab...

The Sand Bubbler Crabs are nature`s micro-recyclers and beach`s secret engineers. They make holes for their shelter and safety. When it comes to their feeding strategy, they pick up the sand and filter out the tiny chunks of organic matter and discard the sand in the form of tiny sand balls. Some crabs use sand balls as a barriers to confuse predators. This behavior help clean the coastal area and contribute to the health of beach ecosystems. These carbs adjust their activity based on temperature and tidal conditions. This is a survival strategy in extreme environmental conditions. This is what we should learn from Sand Bubbler Crabs for adaptability of Climate Change. The crab`s feeding process is a natural example of Circular Economy - Extract the organic matter from the sand and leave the sand in the form of balls and repeat the process each time when the tide returns. Their Presence or absence signals the shift in coastal climate patterns.

Though the act is very small, it is so vital. Climate action begins just like that...a mindful step. 

We have been witnessing the consequences of climate change...but, despite knowing the visible consequences, we continue to stall the efforts to combat climate change and adaptation measures...     Source: UNDP website

Climate Change is Increasing ocean and atmospheric temperatures, and due to which the sea levels are going up and as a result, the frequency of hurricanes, rainfall rates are increasing...

Manage Business Activities:

A business activity can be any organizational activity used to calculate emissions. For example, I have chosen the business activities listed below.

entry.title: Proactive Safety Management with SAP EHS Incident Management
entry.content:
Videos on proactive safety management and on SAP EHS Incident Management:

Proactive Safety Management
SAP EHS Incident Management

How do Incident management and safety culture benefit from integrated software solutions?

Despite decades of improvements in safety management, accident rates in many companies have stagnated. The traditional causes of accidents – technical, organizational, and personal factors – are often marginal today. Instead, it is behaviour-related causes that play a central role. Classical accident management recognizes known causes but usually only intervenes after an event occurs and neglects unknown hazards and risky situations.

Proactive Safety Culture through Transparency and Participation

To sustainably improve the safety level in companies, a proactive safety culture is required that promotes transparency and the active participation of all employees. Here, a software solution like SAP EHS Incident Management plays a central role. This integrated solution enables all operational areas of the company to be made transparent and involves employees by allowing them to record different types of incidents such as accidents, near-misses, and safety observations.

From Reactive to Proactive Action

Safety cultures in companies differ in their approach to accidents. Reactive action only occurs after accidents, preventive action addresses known hazards, while proactive action aims to identify potential hazards early and prevent accidents. To achieve this, transparency is essential. The recording of events – not just accidents, but also near-misses and safety observations – is a central factor.

A study by ConocoPhillips1 Marine shows the quantitative relationship between accidents, near-misses, and safety observations. According to the study, one would have to expect 300,000 so-called 'at risk behaviours’ per fatal accident. The actual accidents are only the tip of the iceberg. The hazard potential is many times greater. Before an accident, risky behaviours often occur, such as disregarding safety precautions, which, if detected, can indicate the potential for accidents. These insights underscore the need to identify hazards early and take proactive measures to prevent serious accidents.

Experts in the field of occupational safety emphasize that the role of management and employee engagement are crucial for the development of a proactive safety culture. A central element is behaviour-based safety (BBS), which aims to eliminate dangerous behaviours and strengthen safety-promoting behaviours among employees. By creating a comprehensive reporting culture within the company, the path to a proactive safety culture is paved.

SAP EHS Incident Management: The Tool for Proactive Safety Culture

SAP EHS Incident Management is an essential building block for a proactive safety culture and behaviour-based safety. This solution provides transparency about all hazards in the company by recording, analysing, and managing accidents, near-misses, and safety observations across all organizational units.

Thanks to integration with HR management, asset management, finance, as well as the organizational and location structure, events can be precisely located and evaluated. The application simplifies the reporting of incidents and ensures that all required information is captured through mandatory fields and validated data selection. By analysing incident statistics, probabilities for serious accidents can be identified early and reduced through preventive measures.

SAP EHS Incident Management is more than just a software solution – it is the central building block for establishing a proactive safety culture that prevents accidents before they happen.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q3-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation
  • Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items
  • GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation
  • Onboarding Booster
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Customer Success Stories: KNAPP & Tyrolit
  • Upcoming Partner Webinars
  • Additional Information

 

ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation

Transportation can be a major contributor to Scope 3 emissions, yet calculating its impact has mostly been complex and manual. With the new ERP‑centric transport footprint calculation, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a capability that leverages your existing ERP master and transactional data to automate and scale transport emission calculations. This means you can move from spreadsheets and estimates to actual, auditable results that integrate seamlessly into both corporate and product carbon footprints.

Instead of building transport models from scratch, the solution now derives upstream and internal transport activities from Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Return to Supplier, and Goods Transfer data, and then calculates the footprint per activity, route, and leg. In practical terms, a transport activity is determined as the movement of specific products in given quantities between two locations under defined conditions. The system brings together master data, transaction details, and transport settings to identify source and target locations, the mode of transport, and whether goods move under ambient or temperature-controlled conditions. It then builds optimal transport routes via connection points such as airports, seaports, inland ports, and railway stations, before applying the relevant emission factors to calculate the footprint.

 

In the following, I’ll briefly summarize the required process steps and introduce the new apps. For detailed information, see Calculating Transport Footprints Using Business Transactions.

To use the new approach, start with importing transport-relevant master data, so routing and distances work out-of-the-box. Products now carry a Custom Temperature Condition, and SAP provides a default mapping to Ambient. If you need temperature-controlled transport, create your own custom conditions and map them to the standard values (Ambient or Temperature-Controlled). Locations and Plants now support addresses and geo-coordinates, and Business Partners can be imported with Supplier and Carrier roles, including address data tied to supplier IDs.

Then you can configure your inventory scope and in Transport Details set the Data Source to Standard (Business Transactions). Newly created scopes default to Standard, while existing scopes remain on Classic until you switch them.

For maintaining transport connection points – like seaports, inland ports, airports, railway stations – go to the Manage Locations app, where you already find SAP-delivered content for seaports and airports to help kick-start sea and air routes.

Next, configure how goods typically move in your network with the new Manage Transport Settings app. Define haul types and distances – short haul defaults to 1500 km and can be adapted – and specify the primary mode of transport from supplier locations to one or all plants, optionally by product group. The same supplier-to-plant mode applies to returns back to the supplier. For internal logistics, create directional settings for movements between plants.

With settings in place, use the new Manage Transport Activities app to generate transport activities for your chosen scope and period from the ERP transactions. Once activities are clean, generate the corresponding routes and legs. In case of inconsistencies, the app guides you with messages helping you to resolve before calculation.

Emission factors for the different modes of transport are managed in the new Manage Transport Operation Footprints app, and you can maintain them in the UI directly or import via file.

Finally, run the transport calculation in the new Calculate Transport Footprints app and review results per activity, route, and leg.

In the Calculate Footprints app, the Data Readiness tab lists transport data as one of the data types. Transport is now a first-class citizen across the analytics experience. In organizational footprint inventories, transport data becomes mandatory whenever your scope uses Standard and transport-relevant value chain steps are enabled. Transport footprints are created as input items to products, if a carrier is specified, the corresponding business partner footprint is used as the utilized item, otherwise the input is shown as Unknown Carrier. You can see transport-related product and business partner items in the Manage Footprint Results app, and analyze Scope 3.4 emissions in depth in the Footprint Overview app.

A quick note on provisioning: The new apps require explicit role assignment, role names are case-sensitive, and write access requires both read and write roles. If you’re moving from the classic transport approach, reimport your enhanced master data for Plants, Business Partners, Products, and relevant Locations via file or API, then switch your inventory scopes to Standard (Business Transactions). Keep scopes on Classic if you plan to recalculate them using the classic transport apps. With these pieces in place, the new transport calculation streamlines data preparation, strengthens routing fidelity, and brings transport emissions seamlessly into your product and corporate footprint story.

 

Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items

For decarbonizing your company and products, it’s crucial to have full transparency into what’s actually driving emissions across the value chain. While total product footprints are useful, they often leave a critical question unanswered: Where exactly do these emissions come from? Without that level of granularity, it’s difficult to identify hotspots, prioritize reduction efforts, or make informed decisions that lead to real impact. To address this, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management now includes a new feature in the Manage Footprint Results app: Source Input Items. This enhancement gives you a detailed view into the specific inputs that contribute to a product’s environmental footprint – enabling smarter, data-driven strategies for decarbonization.

 

Source input items represent the materials, energy, transport, and other resources used at the start of a process that result in emissions. With just a click on Generate, you can now explore these contributors for each footprint item (excluding items of type business partner, work in progress, production documents, and supplier). Note that source input items currently cannot yet be generated for calculation results involving cycles, this will be added in a future release.

The app provides you with various charts that instantly visualize emissions across lifecycle stages such as material acquisition, production, transport, and end-of-life treatment. These charts help you pinpoint the most emission-intensive stages and align your analysis with the GHG Protocol. You can also customize the view to match your specific reporting or decision-making needs. Below the chart, a consolidated table provides full transparency into each source input item.

With this enhancement, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management strengthens its role as an intuitive product fact sheet, empowering you to go beyond high-level metrics. You can now trace emissions to their source, understand their context, and take targeted action – whether that means switching suppliers, optimizing logistics, or redesigning products. For all information, see Viewing the Footprint Results on SAP Help.

 

GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation

One of the recurring challenges in tracking greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is the complexity and scale of data collection. Sustainability teams often need to gather activity and spend data from various business units, geographies, or partner organizations. To address these hurdles, we now released the GHG Data Forms API. This new public API empowers you to extend and tailor the GHG data collection process far beyond the core application: External workflows, survey applications, or even mobile apps can now retrieve, maintain, and push data directly into the GHG Data Forms in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. By decentralizing and parallelizing how and where environmental data is gathered, you can drive faster, more automated, and more consistent emission data capture across your full operational or organizational boundary. For technical details and integration guidelines, refer to the official API documentation on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

One powerful example of leveraging this API is through SAP Build Process Automation. With SAP Build workflows, you can automate and streamline sustainability data collection across multiple locations. The process begins by triggering a workflow, either manually or on a scheduled basis, then retrieving all relevant business activities and locations from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management using the API. Through parallel subprocesses for each location, you can enable simultaneous data collection and significantly reduce cycle time. Business users receive customizable forms – survey-style via SAP Build or ticket-style via SAP Task Center – delivered directly to the right people based on responsibility rules, with built-in notifications and reminders to keep the process moving. Once data is submitted, it’s routed for approval, and after validation, posted back to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and included into the overall footprint calculation. This approach provides flexibility, scalability, and compliance, helping sustainability teams focus on insights rather than manual tasks.

 

 

Onboarding Booster

With the introduction of the Onboarding Booster, we’re speeding up the time required for setting up am SAP Sustainability Footprint Management tenant on SAP BTP. The entire onboarding can now be completed in about 10 to 15 minutes through a guided, automated process. The booster is integrated into the SAP BTP cockpit and walks you through the essential steps: checking prerequisites, selecting the identity service, and either creating or choosing a subaccount. Once these steps are confirmed, the system takes over and performs the necessary configurations in the background. The result is a fully prepared environment that is ready for role assignment and productive use. This is more than just a time saver, it reduces complexity and lowers the barrier for customers to get started quickly and confidently. For detailed guidance, the full procedure is documented in our Help Portal: Setting Up Using Booster.

 

Other Release Highlights

We’ve redesigned the SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure for a more intuitive experience. New app groups offer logical organization, simplifying navigation and helping you to quickly find what you need. For more information, see Enhanced SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure.

You can now assign different location types (not just plants) to a single business activity, expanding flexibility, supporting more accurate form generation, and ensuring that business activities can be valid across multiple locations. See Creating Business Activities for more information.

Additionally, when setting your footprint inventory scope, plant assignments now ensure that only relevant forms are generated for your selected companies and locations. This prevents the creation of irrelevant forms, enhancing efficiency and streamlining the data collection process. Learn more here: Creating Business Activities.

 

Customer Success Stories

KNAPP AG, a global leader in intralogistics and warehouse automation, faced new challenges with the EU’s Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD), which raised the bar for ESG transparency. Instead of waiting for deadlines, KNAPP acted early, building a strong sustainability data foundation with SAP Sustainability solutions. Partnering with KPMG Austria, KNAPP implemented SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower to replace manual reporting with automated, integrated processes. These solutions consolidated over 200 sustainability metrics from across the business, delivering advanced carbon footprint calculations at both product and corporate levels. This gave KNAPP unprecedented visibility into emissions, resource use, and overall ESG impact. With audit-ready reporting in place, KNAPP achieved CSRD compliance well ahead of schedule and embedded sustainability insights into daily operations and strategic planning. This proactive approach turned compliance into a catalyst for transformation, accelerating their “now4tomorrow” program and ensuring their first sustainability report complements financial disclosures. Read the full story: Getting ahead of regulatory reporting to steer business process transformation.

Tyrolit is a global leader in abrasive tools and construction systems that operates across 48 companies and exports to 140+ countries. Also facing growing demands for transparent ESG reporting under CSRD, Tyrolit needed to move beyond fragmented systems and spreadsheets that made standardization and auditability difficult. To address this, Tyrolit deployed SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower, integrated via SAP Business Technology Platform. This centralized ESG data collection from SAP and third-party systems, aligned sustainability reporting with financial standards, and enabled advanced analytics for benchmarking and target setting. AI-powered automation reduced manual work, improved accuracy, and provided dashboards for 60+ managers to monitor 80+ ESG metrics. This resulted in measurable carbon reductions, less plastic packaging, and higher recycling rates. Tyrolit now uses data-driven insights to identify emission-saving opportunities and embed sustainability across the organization. Check the full story: Tooling up to unlock the sustainable value chain with a robust ESG data foundation.

 

Upcoming Partner Webinars

Staying ahead means staying informed, and this quarter again brings two opportunities exclusively for our partners to connect and learn more about SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Both webinars are free for partners with a valid SAP Learning Hub license.

The SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training is a biannual event designed to empower partners with in-depth product know-how, practical guidance, and the latest innovations across SAP Cloud ERP, the SAP Business Suite, AI-powered features, and more. On October 10, you can learn more about the latest updates in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange. Register for the session here: Sustainability Management and Carbon Accounting. For an overview of all sessions and their respective registration links check out: SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training 2025.

On November 5, the Meet the Expert Session returns. This highly interactive webinar is your chance to bring questions directly to the SAP experts from the Product Management and Customer Adoption teams. Gain practical insights, obtain answers to your questions, and deepen your expertise in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Register here: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management - Meet the Expert Q4 2025.

 

Additional Information

To learn more on how you can enhance the accuracy of your Scope 3.1 emissions reporting by transitioning from broad average data to precise, supplier-specific actuals, you should check out the blog post Implementing an Average to Actuals Strategy for Scope 3.1 by @CButzlaff. This article outlines a practical, phased approach for implementing this strategy using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange.

For a comprehensive guide on how to embed carbon accounting into your ERP and finance processes, have a look into the new SAP PRESS book Carbon Accounting for Sustainability with SAP. It explains how to capture sustainability data across your ERP landscape, calculate product- and company-level carbon footprints, and integrate results into finance through SAP Green Ledger. You’ll also learn how SAP Sustainability Data Exchange and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management enable accurate, auditable carbon data for decision-making and reporting.

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. entry.title: Tracking scope3 emissions using SAP SDX
entry.content:
Sustainability has become one of the defining leadership challenges of our time. It is no longer a reporting obligation but a factor that shapes competitiveness, investor confidence, and the trust of customers and communities. Many companies have already made progress by reducing the emissions they control directly through their operations (Scope 1) and their purchased energy (Scope 2). The harder truth is that most of the impact lies elsewhere. Scope 3 emissions created across supply chains, logistics, travel, and end use of products often account for more than 70 percent of a company’s total footprint.

Because they sit outside direct control, these emissions are often underreported and overlooked. Yet leaving them unaddressed carries serious consequences: exposure to new regulations, declining ESG scores, and loss of stakeholder trust. The path forward is clear. Businesses must extend responsibility beyond their own walls, working with partners, suppliers, and customers to create transparency and accountability across the value chain.

Following are the key challenges for businesses committed to sustainability for scope3 emissions:

  • Trust and Verification: Gathering comprehensive and accurate data from across the value chain is a difficult task. Companies must access multiple suppliers, each with their own reporting standards and capabilities, making the consolidation and verification of data a significant hurdle.
  •  Standardization: Without standardized metrics and reporting frameworks, comparing emissions data across suppliers or industry benchmarks becomes challenging. This lack of standardization hampers the ability of businesses to make informed decisions regarding their supply chain practices. 
  • Accurate Data collection: In an era where greenwashing is a growing concern, establishing the credibility of reported emissions data is paramount. Companies need mechanisms to verify the authenticity and accuracy of the data they receive to ensure it truly reflects their environmental impact.

SAP SDX for Scope 3 Emissions Management

The SAP Sustainability Data Exchange solution addresses above challenges and allows to exchange ‘Scope 3’ product footprint data with supply chain partners. The exchange of footprint data allows organizations to move away from using averages and estimates and use primary data instead. As a result, it helps companies to increase the data accuracy of their footprint calculations.

Some of the key product features for SDX are listed below :

Sno

Feature

Description

1

Exchange footprint data with supply chain partners

SAP Sustainability Data Exchange enables the exchange of product footprint data between partners. For purchased products, footprint data can be requested and received from connected suppliers. For sold products, footprint data can be sent to connected customers

2

Review and manage footprint data

SAP Sustainability Data Exchange allows you to review and manage your received (from suppliers) or calculated footprint data.

3

Integrate footprint data to and from other business applications

SAP Sustainability Data Exchange supports the integration of product footprint data to and from other business applications. Footprint data received from suppliers can be distributed to other applications (for example, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management). Similarly, footprint data can be imported and sent to customers.

SAP SDX enables data exchange by requesting and sharing carbon data. It achieves following advantages while exchanging data across supply chain:

Collaboration: It enables sharing of actual product carbon footprints (PCF) across value chains with increased interoperability and data sovereignty of data owners

Standardization: It simplifies audits with standardized data models and workflows and exchange information seamlessly following industry frameworks and requirements

Carbon reduction: It Identifies products or processes with high potential for CO2 reduction, avoid double emissions counting and optimize footprints

Industry specific Solutions: It enables industry specific extensions with WBCSD for e.g. adoptions of the Catena-X data model as an accepted PACT data model for automotive

SAP Sustainability Data Exchange is open for everyone across complex supply chains. Some of its unique integrations are:

  • Cloud-based solution with open APIs
  • Independent of company size
  • Industry agnostic
  • Interoperability: Communicate and exchange data with different systems and programs

Conclusion

In today's rapidly evolving world, the Energy and Utilities Industry are at the forefront of addressing sustainability challenges. With a strong commitment to reducing carbon footprints and minimizing emissions, the industry is taking significant strides towards a greener future. Emissions, particularly greenhouse gases, are a major concern as they are released during activities such as emissions from purchased goods such as manufacturing equipment, solar panels, wind turbines, and other components used in energy production. Additionally, emissions from losses in power grids and pipelines during delivery contribute significantly to scope 3 emissions. By leveraging innovative solutions and technologies, the Energy and Utilities Industry is poised to make a substantial impact in mitigating these environmental challenges and achieving their sustainability goals.

As Energy and Utilities industry are gearing up to tackle these challenges, TCS, which is a strategic partner of SAP, could help them tackle these challenges with the help of SAP SDX . TCS, which is a technology consulting firm, would help industry in setting up the systems, enabling the required data transfers into the systems through SAP SDX - achieve sustainable supply chains by requesting and sharing carbon data.

entry.title: Building Sustainable Supply Chains: From Design to Reuse
entry.content:
Building Sustainable Supply Chains: From Design to Reuse

Sustainability is no longer just a nice-to-have; it’s a business must. Customers, regulators, and investors expect companies to take responsibility not only for their own operations but also for the environmental and social impact across their entire supply chain. That’s where the concept of double materiality comes in: it examines both how sustainability risks and opportunities affect a company's financial performance and how its activities impact society and the environment.

The challenge? Supply chains are sprawling, multi-tiered networks that cross industries, continents, and regulatory systems. But within this complexity lies opportunity. With the right strategy, processes, and technology, companies can build supply chains that are not only resilient and compliant but also drivers of long-term value.

In this blog, we’ll explore how organizations can move step by step—from design to reuse—towards building truly sustainable supply chains, and we’ll highlight some of the SAP solutions that make this transformation possible.

Why Sustainable Supply Chains Matter

Supply chains are at the heart of the sustainability challenge. In industries such as automotive, consumer goods, and manufacturing, they can account for the majority of a company’s carbon footprint. Scope 3 emissions, encompassing those from suppliers, logistics, and product use, can account for more than 70% of a company's total greenhouse gas (GHG) impact.

And carbon is just one piece of the puzzle. Companies must also navigate regulatory requirements, such as EUDR and CBAM, improve resource efficiency, reduce waste, and prepare for climate-related risks, including water shortages and flooding. It sounds daunting, but within this complexity lies a real opportunity.

Think of the supply chain as a circle rather than a straight line:

  • Design sets the stage. Choices about materials, packaging, and product life cycles determine environmental impact long before anything is produced.
  • Plan and Procure shape how responsibly resources are sourced and how suppliers are engaged in meeting sustainability goals.
  • Manufacture is about efficiency and using less energy and water, generating less waste, and embedding circular practices into production.
  • Delivery focuses on logistics: reducing emissions in transportation, optimizing routes, and rethinking packaging.
  • The product usage shifts the spotlight to the customer, where durability, repairability, and energy efficiency influence both sustainability and satisfaction.
  • Reuse closes the loop through recycling, remanufacturing, or creating entirely new business models around product-as-a-service.

 

This circular approach transforms sustainability from a compliance exercise into a growth engine. Companies that weave sustainability into every step of their supply chain can cut costs, win customer trust, unlock new markets, and build resilience against disruptions.

Smart Design, Lower Impact

Take the example of a car seat. Sustainability starts in the design phase: the choice of materials, say eco-friendly upholstery instead of leather, has an immediate impact on the product’s footprint. In fact, leather use can trigger regulatory requirements in certain markets, such as the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) compliance in Europe. Beyond materials, the way the seat is designed also matters. A seat that’s easy to disassemble makes it simpler to recycle components or reuse some material later, extending its lifecycle.

This is where technology comes in. SAP Responsible Design and Production helps manufacturers anticipate future Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) fees, giving them the insight to make smarter design and packaging decisions upfront. Meanwhile, SAP Green Token offers chain-of-custody transparency for certified sustainable and recycled materials, providing the credibility companies need to back sustainability claims, including compliance with regulations like EUDR.

In addition, with SAP Product and REACH Compliance, manufacturers can assess and document the environmental compatibility and regional marketability of their products.

From Cost to Carbon: Why Supply Chain Planning Needs a Sustainability Upgrade

Supply chain planning has traditionally focused on three things: cost, availability, and quality. But today, there’s a new non-negotiable: sustainability. Take the former example of a car seat: if the design calls for leather, then in Europe that leather must be EUDR-certified. Certifications like this shouldn’t be seen as an afterthought; they need to carry the same weight in planning as cost or quality.

And it goes beyond compliance. In the past, planners compared scenarios to find the best margins or service levels. Now, the question is just as much about impact: Which scenario delivers the lowest carbon footprint?

Smarter planning naturally leads to less waste. Optimizing inventory and capacity not only improves efficiency and saves money, but it also reduces emissions, creating better outcomes for both the business and the planet.

For global manufacturers, this matters even more. Europe requires EUDR-certified leather, while other markets may not. By weaving sustainability into planning, companies can stay compliant in every region without sacrificing efficiency.

This is where solutions like SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) make a difference. IBP allows companies to embed sustainability into every step in the process, treating certifications as sustainability attributes, simulating emissions across scenarios, and flagging ESG risks before they escalate.

The bottom line: Future-proof supply chains don’t just balance cost and service; they balance cost, service, compliance, and environmental impact.

Procurement as a Catalyst for Sustainability

Procurement isn’t just about negotiating the best price or ensuring materials arrive on time; it's also about managing risk and optimizing supply chain efficiency. Every buying decision has a ripple effect on a company’s sustainability footprint, making procurement one of the most powerful levers for driving meaningful change.

Suppliers are validated based on their overall risk profile. This does include their exposure to climate change-related risks, their mitigation strategies, certifications, and overall sustainability performance. In our example of EUDR-certified leather, it is about the validation that the leather has not been produced by farms with deforestation practices. In addition, suppliers are requested to share the carbon footprint of their products, the calculation method, and potentially assurance documents. The capability of exchanging sustainability data, such as scope 3 emission data, across the value chain becomes crucial for collaboration to hit greenhouse targets. Analyzing the carbon footprint of different material choices allows companies to make informed sourcing decisions and balance cost, quality, and sustainability.

SAP offers multiple solutions to help customers. Embedding sustainability attributes into the risk assessment using SAP Ariba Supplier Risk helps to manage climate-related risks. Using SAP Sustainability Data Exchange supports a standardized and certified way to exchange sustainability data, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management calculates and analyzes emissions tied to product purchases, transportation, and manufacturing, and finally, SAP Green Token helps companies to be compliant with EUDR regulations.

When procurement leaders embrace these tools and practices, they move from simply buying materials to actively driving decarbonization and ensuring compliance. Sustainable buying isn’t a “nice to have” anymore; it’s a game-changer for business and the planet.

Beyond Compliance: Embedding Sustainability Into Manufacturing Operations

Once raw materials arrive at the factory floor, the responsibility shifts from sourcing to production. At this stage, manufacturers face a critical challenge: how to minimize energy use, conserve water, cut waste, ensure worker safety, and stay compliant with evolving regulations.

Sustainable manufacturing isn’t just about checking boxes; it’s about embedding smarter processes that strengthen resilience and competitiveness. Here’s how leading companies are approaching it:

  • Energy and emissions tracking: By modeling energy flows across production lines, manufacturers can allocate emissions directly to activities and products, providing the transparency required to develop and track decarbonization strategies.

  • Waste reduction: Cradle-to-grave waste management and recycling programs help eliminate inefficiencies and reduce environmental impact.

  • Worker health and safety: Predictive tools highlight potential hazards, while real-time tracking improves visibility into incidents and ensures safer working conditions.

Take upholstery manufacturing as an example. By modeling the energy flow of a production line, businesses can calculate the carbon footprint of each unit produced. This not only enables accurate product-level sustainability reporting but also highlights where efficiency gains can be made.

To enable this shift, technology plays a vital role. SAP solutions help manufacturers close the loop:

  • #SAP Environment Management monitors emissions, waste, and compliance across operations

  • #SAP Workplace Safety strengthens incident visibility and fosters a culture of safety

  • SAP Sustainability Footprint Management  calculates product footprints based on measured data for transparent reporting

When done right, sustainable manufacturing reduces risk, ensures compliance, and delivers products with smaller footprints, turning sustainability into a competitive advantage.

Sustainable Logistics: Reducing Emissions Beyond the Factory Gate

Once a product leaves the factory, its journey has only just begun. Trucks, ships, and planes carry it across regions and continents, but these movements come at a cost. The logistics and distribution phase is one of the biggest contributors to supply chain emissions. The good news? Smarter delivery models are proving that it’s possible to move goods efficiently while shrinking environmental impact. 

It starts with transportation optimization. By consolidating shipments, reducing empty miles, and adopting low-carbon fuels, companies can cut unnecessary emissions while saving costs.  Just as important is knowing how much carbon is being released. By tracking emissions from different types of transport and sharing that information with customers, companies can be more transparent, helping customers to make better, more eco-friendly decisions. 

Collaboration plays a powerful role, too. By sharing carbon footprint data with customers and partners, manufacturers can build trust and enable joint action. For example, the automotive supplier calculates the full carbon footprint of the car seats from the material used, the inbound transport of those materials, through manufacturing energy use, to outbound delivery. The results are shared with OEM partners via Catena-X, creating a shared foundation for decarbonization across the value chain.

Technology is what makes these advances scalable:

  • SAP Transportation Management optimizes routing and freight networks, reducing both emissions and costs.

  • SAP Sustainability Footprint Management calculates carbon emissions, including scope 3.1 as well as logistics-based emissions such as scope 3.4 and 3.9 categories.

  • SAP Sustainability Data Exchange enables transparent and secure sharing of carbon data across networks

By embedding sustainability into logistics, companies can reduce costs, meet rising customer expectations, and support Scope 3 reporting, all while ensuring their products reach the right place at the right time with a lighter footprint.

Closing the Loop: How Circular Supply Chains Create New Value

The final stage of a product’s life cycle isn’t really the end; it’s the beginning of a new cycle. That’s the power of circular supply chains: they extend product life, recover valuable resources, and dramatically cut waste. It starts with managing and auditing waste streams responsibly, making sure even hazardous materials are handled the right way. From there, recycled inputs can be looped back into production, reducing the need for virgin resources and shrinking the footprint of every product made. Partnerships with recyclers and waste handlers play a big role too, creating steady, sustainable flows of materials that companies can depend on. But one of the most powerful strategies is remanufacturing and reuse. By reusing components and remanufacturing products closer to home, companies recover higher value while cutting both costs and emissions tied to sourcing and logistics. This approach strengthens ties with suppliers and gives both providers and customers a chance to reduce waste and build more sustainable products together. In our example, car seat fabrics might not just be made from recycled plastics supplied by disposal companies, but also combined with cork-based materials to meet demand, lowering reliance on new resources while delivering products that customers want. SAP helps bring these strategies to life.  SAP Environment, Health, and Safety Management ensures compliance and auditing of waste streams, SAP Integrated Business Planning balances demand and supply for recycled inputs, and SAP Waste and Recycling makes it easier to collaborate with recyclers and waste handlers. The impact speaks for itself: car seat manufacturers, adopting circular supply chain practices, have cut carbon emissions by 52% through smarter routing and sustainable materials, reduced per-seat emissions by 34%, and made emissions reporting 75 times faster. Circular supply chains don’t just close the loop; they create new opportunities for efficiency, savings, and competitive advantage. The final stage is not the end but the beginning of a new cycle. Circular supply chains extend product life, recover resources, and reduce waste.

Conclusion: The Future of Supply Chains Is Sustainable, Digital, and Circular

Sustainable supply chains are no longer a niche initiative. They are central to regulatory compliance, market differentiation, and long-term resilience. By embedding sustainability from design to reuse, organizations can cut carbon emissions and waste, ensure compliance with global regulations, build stronger supplier and customer relationships, and unlock entirely new circular business models. Technology is the enabler. With SAP'sSustainabilitysolutions,  companies can move beyond fragmented initiatives to an integrated, data-driven approach that turns sustainability into a growth engine.
 
As Can Üstünberk, Executive Board Member at MarturFompak International, puts it: “We are working passionately to adapt emerging technologies to all of our business processes and to create a ‘New Digital and Sustainable’ business model—to make it more resilient, more competitive, and above all to create a more Sustainable World.”
The future of supply chains is sustainable, digital, and circular. The companies that act decisively today will be the leaders of tomorrow.
 
This blog has explored how organizations can transform their supply chains step by step, from design to reuse, and how SAP solutions can make that transformation a reality.

entry.title: Managing Compliance Register in SAP EHS: Boosting Transparency and Control
entry.content:
In today’s sustainability driven business environment, organizations are continuously adapting to new regulatory frameworks from environmental permits to occupational health and safety obligations.
With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, SAP EHS Compliance Management is designed to centralize this process, ensuring that businesses can track, monitor, and demonstrate compliance across their operations.


Step-by-Step guide:

  1. Maintaining an Entry in the Compliance Register
    1. Confirm master data
      1. Ensure the Location (site / plant) is created and maintained in the system. (The user creating an entry in the compliance register must be assigned as the "Environmental Manager" under the location's "Person Responsible Tab")
      2. Ensure the Regulation / Permit (parent regulation) and its Requirements / Sub-requirements are created in the system.
    2. Open the Manage Compliance Register app (F8632)
      1. Select the relevant Company / Site / Location and establish a link between the available Compliance obligations. This creates an assignment and it appears on the registers list. (Note that Permits can only be linked to the location to which it was originally maintained with)
    3. Maintain Applicability Status for the Requirements and Sub-requirements
      1. Select an assignment and maintain applicability status for compliance and its requirements.
      2. Under "Requirement's" tab, from All Requirements, update the Applicability and Fulfillment Status for all the items that are in scope.  
      3. By default, Applicability will be set as "Not Assessed"
      4. Applicability Status are as below
        1. Applicable - The requirement applies to your location.
        2. Exempted - The requirement can't be implemented and the authorities have exempted your location from having to comply with it.
        3. Not Applicable - The requirement doesn't apply to your location.
        4. Not Assessed - You haven't yet assessed whether the requirement applies to your location, or a reassessment is required.
    4. Set Fulfilment Status at requirement level
      1. Once the Requirement is applicable, it is possible to create and manage "Tasks". After the necessary tasks are completed, maintain the Fulfillment Status by choosing "Set Status"
      2. Fulfillment status are as below
        1. Fulfilled - You assess the requirement as fulfilled, or you've already planned actions to fulfill it.
        2. Fulfilled with Variance - The requirement is fulfilled with acceptable deviations.
        3. Not Assessed - The status of the requirement is undefined. This is the default status for a newly assigned applicable requirement.
        4. Not Fulfilled - The requirement is unfulfilled because either no actions have been taken, or the actions have failed.
      3. Ensure both Applicability and Fulfillment statuses get updated, and If there is an action required for a requirement (e.g., regulation changed or a task failed), mark Action Required = Yes for that requirement and add the remediation note. Once the action is addressed, choose "Clear Action Required" button which immediately set it to No.

         

      4. Go back to Parent compliance, and update the fulfilment status.
      5. Note: The “Action Required” status auto-updates and triggers an email notification to the responsible person in the following cases:
        1. When a compliance is modified and if the same is already in the register, it changes to “Yes”, indicating review is needed by the Compliance Manager.
        2. If any sub-requirement has Action Required = Yes, the parent compliance also updates to “Yes”.
    5. Change Log Review
      1. Click the “View Change Log” button to view all recorded entries, including location creation, compliance creation, assessment updates, and justifications. This ensures an audit-ready register with complete accountability and transparency.
    6. Maintenance of Compliance register
      1. The Environmental manager must ensure that all the compliance in the register are reviewed and up to date.
         

         

  2. Verify in Operational Compliance Overview (F8787)
    1. Open the Operational Compliance Overview app (F8787)
      1. Maintain the necessary filters and choose "Go".
    2. Compliance Overview cards
      1. Compliance Rate : Displays a percentage based on overall fulfilled and fulfilled with variance counts.
        Colour logic:
        ≤ 30% → Red
        > 30% and < 60% → Orange
        ≥ 60% → Green
      2. Obligation Applicability : Displays the total number of obligations categorised by their applicability status. (i.e., which obligations are applicable across locations).
      3. Obligation Fulfilment : Shows the number of obligations by location and their fulfilment status.
      4. Note: Interacting with any section of the chart will navigate back to the Manage Compliance register app. 

By maintaining a structured digital compliance register and having clear visibility in dashboards:

  • Organizations strengthen their ESG governance structure.
  • It enhances audit readiness, since every regulation, task, and status update is traceable.
  • Most importantly, it bridges the gap between regulatory adherence and sustainability accountability, making compliance measurable and reportable.

The 2508 release is another example of SAP’s commitment to continuously improve the sustainability and compliance landscape.
By leveraging these new functionalities, EHS and sustainability teams can move from reactive reporting to proactive compliance management, ensuring that regulatory requirements are met efficiently and transparently.

This blog is intended for knowledge sharing and aims to help readers better understand and explore SAP Sustainability solutions. I hope it provided valuable insights into the topic discussed. In the upcoming blogs, I’ll continue sharing key functionalities, practical use cases, and best practices that can help organizations in their sustainability and compliance journey.

Stay tuned for more updates and feel free to share your thoughts or questions in the comments below.
